title: Very Old Font 1870s
content:
Can anyone Id the font on the attached image. Its from a sign dated around 1870s.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [FG Sign 1870s letters.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/typophile.com/files/FG%20Sign%201870s%20letters.jpg) | 29.25 KB |
author: rgoer who

comments.content: Looks like some sort of [Bodoni Compressed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/fb-bodoni) but hard to say with the distortion, serifs look bigger on my suggestion. A [Bodoni Condensed Black](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/bodoni-rr-black-condensed) might work as well.

This was a typeface known as "Roman" which was popular during the third quarter of the 19th century. Note the extreme thick-thin contrast like Didot or Bodoni. Also note the huge pointed-wedge shaped beaks on E, G, L, T & S and mini unbracketed serifs. Foundry terminology varied but Roman Extra Condensed Italic, or Roman Elongated Slope would fit. Here is a condensed version, with no slope, from Bruce Foundry 1869.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601im_/http:/typophile.com/files/RomanCond@Bruce1869p55_3914.jpg)
  
AFAIK "Roman" is not digitized in a precise match to your image.  
Don

Thanks to Don, digged a bit more and found these 3 ones, all from Wooden Type Foundry and possibly some digitizations of "Roman" as identified by him: [Roman X](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/roman-x) (no more available to sell unfortunately), [Penny](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/penny) and [Roman Wells](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/roman-wells)

Thanks Ryuk for posting the Wooden Type Foundry fonts. I won't duplicate the references.  
A few more: Matthew Carter's [Elephant Regular](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.linotype.com/899985/Regular-product.html/) is a well designed presentation of a design that is somewhere between Thororowgood and the font that formed the basis for your image. Somewhat similar is Monotype's 1931 design for [Falstaff](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/falstaff/). Berthold's 1860 design, [Normand BQ](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/normande-bq/) includes a condensed version and an italic version but not a condesnsed italic. There is also a Bitstream version of Normande.  
Don

For a not exact, but fairly close to your image, rendition of the letters in your image see the following image using Woodentype's Roman Xtra Cond, wqhich also shows the letters with a slope of 4 degrees:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601im_/http:/typophile.com/files/RomanXCondWoodentype_5066.jpg)
  
I have no idea how you could purchase this font. MyFonts does not sell it and the website [http://www.woodentypefonts.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402004601/http:/www.woodentypefonts.com/ "http://www.woodentypefonts.com/"), which used to sell it, merely has a notice in Russian that the website is suspended. Perhaps someone has current info on the foundry?  
Don
